<<Budget>>

Welcome to MyBudgetCoach. I'm so proud of you for taking this first step to get started budgeting, or to try a new budgeting method. My name is Celia and I'm going to guide you through this process.

<<Budget>>

Budgeting can feel overwhelming. It can be hard to get started and even harder to stick with it. I'm here to help break it down into manageable pieces and encourage you along the way.

<<Budget>>

I'm thrilled that you are feeling excited and confident about budgeting. Let's dive right in and get you going.

<<Budget>>

I'm a real person who LOVES to budget and talk about budgets. But my virtual persona is not nearly as good a listener as real life me. My avatar is going to be a great companion to walk you through the budget set up and some budget habits, but if you need a real live listening ear please feel free to book a time for us to meet.

<<Budget>>

How are you feeling about budgeting today?

Nervous
mindset = nervous

Excited
mindset = excited
highlight: zoom_link
Tell me more about who I'd be meeting

<<Budget>>

Here's where you can book a time to chat with me in real life. This would be an additional cost per hour.
I'm ready
My budget categories are already set up

<<Budget>>

The first thing I like to do when setting up a new budget is look at how we want to organize the categories. There are a couple of great options and I'll tell you about each and then let you choose.

Then I'll help you build your budget with categories that fit your life. This is what makes personal finance personal.

<<Budget>>

One option is to organize by frequency of each expense. Monthly bills, frequent/ongoing spending, and non-monthly expenses.

This option is great for people new to budgeting who need to make sure they have the money they need ready when they need it. It also can allow you to focus on smaller amounts of money at a time while you learn.

<<Budget>>

Which do you want to try?

<<Budget>>

You want to organize by frequency, great. I'll help you get that set up.
Let's do it

<<Budget>> 

You want to organize by type. Awesome. I'll help you get that set up. 

Each time you choose an area below it will auto create a group in your budget so only click on areas you want to include (though you can delete them if you change your mind). 

Once you've clicked each one you need you can click "I'm done" to move on.

<<Budget>>

When setting up by frequency I like 3 main sections.
1 - Monthly Bills
2 - Monthly "Live" Spending
3 - Non-Monthly Spending

We will work on each of these sections one at a time.

<<Budget>>

Let's start with monthly bills. I include in this category anything that comes out typically once each month for a predictable amount. It might vary a bit like an electric bill but you can make a reasonable guess at the amount and due date.
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Choose a theme that applies to your life.

<<Budget>>

Here's a quick food category group. You could expand on it by separating groceries into weekly amounts, or by separating dining out into different purposes like socializing vs I forgot to plan ahead vs. I just like coffee, ok.
Back to choices

<<Budget>>

I tried to streamline this but if you want more detail, like separate categories for water, electric and heat please add those. Also if you don't escrow property taxes or insurance or if you have an HOA, you'll need to add those categories. You could also think about if there are any seasonal expenses related to your housing.

My "Big Expenses" category is intended for things like furniture, appliances, repairs etc. "Household Goods" is smaller stuff like toilet paper or a screwdriver.

<<Budget>>

Here are some categories you might need for a car.

<<Budget>>

Don't forget to prioritize joy in your budget. Here are some ideas but please edit them to fit what brings you joy.
Back to choices

<<Budget>><br style="border-color: var(--border-color);"><br style="border-color: var(--border-color);">Here are some categories you might need for kids. But every family is different so I'm sure you have some edits to make here.
Back to choices
Back to choices

<<Budget>>

Here's a start on technology categories. You might choose to separate the subscriptions out into individual categories if that works better for you.
Back to choices

<<Budget>>

These are some boring adult things that cost money so you should probably prepare for them
I tested it out

<<Budget>>

The budget screen can show 1 month at a time or several. Test that out by clicking the calendar icons. Personally I like one month most of the time and two when we're coming up to a month rollover.
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

While it's set to multiple months you can use the months bar here to choose which months are displayed. You might choose this month and last right at the beginning of a month or this month and next toward the end of a month.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget." Currently that amount is zero because we haven't told it about any accounts yet, but when we do I'll come back and explain it further.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

First, I'll give you a quick tour of the budget screen. This is where you will be able to see how much money is available for each expense. It's the core of your budgeting experience.

<<Budget>>

This next bit might feel a bit dry but it's important so you know where to find things later.

<<Budget>>

The main feature on this screen is the budget table. Think of it as a digital envelope system where dollars are waiting to be spent on specific things.

<<Budget>>

The Category column is a list of the things someone plans to spend on. Deciding what to include here is a good way to personalize your budget and feel some ownership.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where we initially place dollars in their envelopes. Each month this amount will show how much was put in in that month.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows what was actually spent out of the budgeted dollars. These numbers will be generated as transactions are entered in accounts and categorized.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what is available to spend. If it's negative and red, the category is overspent. If the amount is black, that's what is left.

<<Budget>>

Even the best budgeters sometimes overspend. That's ok, the next step is to adjust the budget to account for this overspending, that way there's no risk of over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at the three dots next to the category header. This gives visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a category group name in this column (Like Usual Expenses), an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Let's try that. Add a category called "Unicorn Treats".
Magic Wand
I got this

<<Budget>>

Would you like me to wave my magic wand and you edit from there or do you want me to show you a list of ideas and you can add the ones you need manually?

<<Budget>>

Bibbiti Bobbiti Boo

<<Budget>>

I'm so confident you'll rock this. First edit the name of "usual expenses" to "monthly bills". Then use my list and your knowledge of your bills to add categories to the monthly bills group. Also add a second group for monthly bills - wants (more on that in a minute).

Here's my list of ideas:
Rent/Mortgage
Utilities (one category or separate)
Phone
Internet
TV/Streaming
Car Payment
Car Insurance
Debt (one category or a few)
Subscriptions
Gym or other memberships

<<Budget>>

We're off to a great start. Now it's your turn. Go through the list and delete ones that don't apply to your life and add in anything I forgot. Remember this is just for monthly bills at the moment.

I condensed things like water, electric and heat bills into one category for utilities. If you prefer those separated out please go ahead and separate them. Same for things like subscriptions.

<<Budget>>

Great work. I hope that feels good to capture that information in an organized way. Next we'll move on to "Live" spending.
Practice budget here we come
I'm ready for my real budget

<<Budget>>

So in summary, here's the plan

<<Accounts>>

Did you know you can change the name of your budget? Simply click the current name and select "rename budget". Let's call this one "Fantasy Land" so we remember not to use it for real budgeting later.
move_to: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

Nice! Now I'll just walk you through the accounts screen so you know where things are. You can also come back and reset the avatar if you forget.
move_to: center_screen

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account". Name your account "Treasure", select the cash account type and then enter a balance of $576.35.

When you click "create" it will take you to that account screen.

<<Accounts>>

Let's add a practice account for our fantasy land. Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

In MyBudgetCoach we base our budget on the money we currently have, not an estimate of what we'll earn in a month. That makes the accounts section a key part of the budget because it tracks how much money we have available.

I have no credit cards

Got that number? Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

In order to keep track of your spending within your budget we will add each credit card as it's own account. Please go find out the current balances.

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete this transaction. If you hover over the transaction you'll see a checkbox appear to the left of the date. Select the box to select the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

This same process for adding transactions will work in credit card accounts or really any account type. Think of it like an old school balancing of your checkbook, but much faster and less math.

<<Accounts>>

Select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove the transaction.
Account set up
Category Set up

<<Budget>>

...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...

<<Budget>>

There's a quick survey that lets you provide me with feedback so I can be the best version of my virtual self.
I submitted the form

<<Budget>>

Great! Here's the link: https://airtable.com/appYAaDkGzB3ecOzl/shrUnpE9sHBWWDMyB

<<Budget>>

Thanks so much! Happy budgeting!
User Survey after Tutorial

<<Budget>>

You are doing so great. The key to experiencing budgeting joy and success is consistency so keep coming back and working with your budget. I'll pop up every now and then to offer guidance.

<<Budget>>

If you need some extra encouragement or have specific questions don't hesitate to book a video call with me (budget for it first).

<<Budget>>

Remember, the key to long term success is sticking with it.
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
move_to: zoom_link

<<Budget>>

You already have a budget. Awesome. 

I'll offer a few quick ideas for optional ways you could edit it and then we'll move on.

<<Budget>>

I recommend grouping your budget by frequency of expenses if you're new to budgeting. By that I mean monthly fixed bills as one group. Frequent "live" spending like groceries or dining out as another group. Then less frequent non-monthly expenses as a third group.

Within each of those groups if you have many categories it can be helpful to split into a group of wants and a group of needs.

This helps make it easy to see what you need to budget for in what order as money comes in.

<<Budget>>

If money is less tight and your reason for budgeting is better awareness of your spending then organizing by thematic groups works really well.

So you'd have a group for house, car, kids, food and so on. Within each group you might want to put things in order of priority, like monthly car payment and gas towards the top and saving for the next car further down.

<<Budget>>

If these ideas have made you rethink things you can drag and drop your categories to rearrange them.

<<Budget>>

One final tip before we move on to setting up your accounts.

It can be hard to remember specific things like exactly how much Netflix costs each month or how much you need to budget monthly for an annual membership. 

If you hover over a category name there's a small paper icon. Click that and you can add notes. I like to put the amount, due date if applicable and any other details here. This way I'm not always having to look things up when I'm trying to focus on budgeting.

Congratulations. You just built your budget.

<<Budget>>

Before we move over to the account screen please take some time if you haven't already to go through the categories I suggested and delete those that don't apply to you and add in any that I forgot.

<<Budget>>

Another option is to organize by type of expense, grouping house expenses together, car expenses etc. 

This option is great for people who are budgeting to help get a better idea where their money is going. Maybe you always have enough but want to gain some insight and optimize.

<<Accounts>>

You have three options for keeping accounts up to date in MyBudgetCoach. One is simply entering transactions manually. Another is downloading a file from your bank and importing that. The third option is using a third party syncing software (SimpleFIN). For the moment we're going to stick with manual entry while we learn (and because fantasy land doesn't have banks to import from).

<<Budget>>

If my face is in the way while you're learning try out different month displays to help.

<<Budget>>

Now that you've made your list I want you to sort it into wants and needs. You can do this by just clicking and dragging the categories into the wants group. We're still only focusing on fixed monthly bills but some of those might be more necessary than others.

I am not here to judge your priorities (and unless we meet on zoom I can't even see them) but it will make the budgeting part easier if you've already made some decisions about what's most important.

You also might want to drag the bills so they're in roughly chronological order, things due earlier in the month towards the top and so on.

<<Budget>>

When I say "Live" spending I mean any time you're an active participant in the spending. This could be buying gas at the pump, ordering take out on your phone or an Amazon order from your home computer.

<<Budget>>

So let's think about all the things you spend money on during most months. We will save things that are less frequent than monthly for our next groups. 

Once again we will be sorting our categories into needs and wants to help us with our budgeting later.

Some will be obvious, others you might not be sure where they fit for you. Go with your gut and adjust later, nothing is set in stone.

<<Budget>>

Go ahead and delete what you don't need and add anything I forgot.

<<Budget>>

This last section is one that is often overlooked in traditional budgeting since we're so used to looking at monthly expenses. But there are many expenses that don't occur every month. Instead of letting them sneak up on us we're going to plan for them.

<<Budget>>

These will be our Non-Monthly expenses. Some of them are boring like car registration and others are fun like travel. We will sort these into needs and wants too. One rule I have for myself for these kinds of categories is "would I be willing to go into debt for this if it came around and I wasn't prepared for it?" If the answer is yes (like the car repairs) then it's a need and I make sure that my monthly budget can support saving for my non-monthly needs before I spend on monthly wants.

Nicely done! Just go ahead and sort those if you haven't already and then your budget is done. Ok, it's never really done. There will always be new things to add and expenses you don't have anymore. But this is a great start and it can grow and evolve with you over time.

<<Budget>>

We set up the two sides of the budget, the categories and the accounts, and we practiced tracking some spending. You’re making such strong progress.

<<Budget>>

Now we get to practice the actual budgeting part of the process. This might feel very different to what you expect budgeting to look like. The main difference is that you’re only going to budget with money that you have right now instead of predicting how much money you will have for the month.

<<Budget>>

Basically we will take our current cash on hand and allocate that money to various categories depending on how we plan to spend it.

<<Budget>>

Here at the top it shows us how much money we have to budget.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

Would you like an analogy or an example?
I'll give you a chance to read both if you want.

<<Budget>>

Imagine you live 50 years ago, when digital banking wasn’t the norm.  You’re doing your budgeting with a pile of cash and a bunch of envelopes. You put that cash into different envelopes so you know how much is for groceries and how much is for the electric bill. You can’t put cash you don’t have yet in envelopes.

<<Budget>>

Let’s say I have $500 in the bank right now and it’s the middle of the month. I probably don’t need to use any of that money for rent because I already paid that this month. So instead of looking at a generic month budget I look ahead at what’s coming up in real life.

<<Budget>>

Perhaps my phone bill is $120 and due in 3 days. I budget $120 to that. That leaves $380. I know I’m going out for a friend’s birthday this weekend so I put $80 in that category, leaving $300. Typically I spend $150/week on groceries and $50 on gas, so I budget those amounts. That leaves $100 and I don’t have any other immediate needs in the next week before I get another paycheck so I budget the $100 to my travel savings.

<<Budget>>

Then when I get my next paycheck I once again look at bills coming up, regular expenses like groceries, irregular things based on the reality of my next few weeks, and then looking ahead further if I can.
Nope, I got it

<<Budget>>

Do you want to circle back to hear the other?
I took a break and I'm ready for the real thing
Break time

<<Budget>>

All done with the practice budget. Are you ready to try it with your real life? This might be a great time to step away for a bit and let the new ideas sink in. Don't be gone too long, I'll be here waiting.

Part 1
Interactive Practice
1. Categories
2. Accounts
3. Budgeting

Part 2
Your Real Budget
1. Categories
2. Accounts
3. Budgeting

<<Budget>>

If you wanted to make a plan for upcoming paychecks you might also jot down notes on the outside of the envelope like “car payment, $200, 25th” so that when you get paid you remember how much to put in. But that doesn’t mean you can pay the car payment before you put the cash in the envelope.

<<Budget>>

By keeping the money in separate envelopes you avoid accidentally spending the electric bill money on groceries. It also lets you easily see at a glance what you can safely spend on dining out or clothes without shorting yourself elsewhere.
If I have time, add more examples and support here upon request. OR add a zoom call prompt (or both)

<<Budget>>

I want you to look at your money that you have available and let’s make some choices about what that money needs to do.

<<Budget>>

If at any point in this process you run out of money, stop budgeting, hit the “I’m done” button and I’ll talk you through the next steps.
Keep going
I'm done

<<Budget>>

You want to think about when you are getting paid next and start with any bills that have due dates between now and when you get paid. Fill those in with the amounts needed.
Keep going
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Next,  look at your calendar for the time period until your next expected income and think about anything that is coming up that costs money. That might be a doctor’s appointment or a birthday party or a haircut. Fill those in. Make a guess about the amount if it can vary.
There's still more money
I'm done

<<Budget>>

You will also need to put money into the categories for things that happen often, most commonly these are groceries and gas but your budget might include other frequent expenses. Put money in all of these. But you don’t need to put in a whole month worth, just enough until you get paid again.
I'm done

<<Budget>>

You’ve accounted for all your immediate needs and still have money left to budget. That’s awesome. I’ll give you a few things to think about so that we can make sure all that money is safely in budget categories. 

Deciding what the money is for before spending it is a really important step in having a successful budget. I've saved the "I'm done" option for the end of these suggestions so you can click through them all and make an informed choice with the rest of your money.

<<Budget>>

Ok, did you budget exactly to zero? If not, go ahead and make a quick adjustment. 

Specifically, if "to budget" has a few dollars left go ahead and put exactly that amount in a future bill, savings goal or fun money or something. 

If you’ve gone a bit into the negative then adjust a category so it has a bit less and "to budget" is back up to zero.

<<Budget>>

Nicely done, now, if you had to stop before you covered your needs that’s important information for you. It means you might have to delay some needs or get creative until you’re paid again. 

If you met all your needs then you can feel comfortable spending those funds, but be sure to check the budget if you spend on things you hadn’t planned on.

<<Budget>>

Is some of the remaining money because you’d already been saving up for specific things like an upcoming car repair, vacation or other large expense? Budget funds to those categories based on what you’d already planned to do with that money.

<<Budget>>

Are there times of the month when your bills cluster and things get tight with that paycheck? You could consider budgeting some money to those bills ahead of time so it’s not so tight then.

<<Budget>>

Are there longer term expenses that you could start saving for, like annual memberships, seasonal clothing shopping, planting a garden or holidays?
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Do you have debt you can work on paying down? Or big savings goals like retirement that you want to work on bulking up?

Now go ahead and budget the remainder of your money.

<<Budget>>

Now that all your money is budgeted I want to show you something. Look at the number next to “for budget” in the far left column.
move_to: for_budget_accounts

<<Budget>>

Now look at the number under “balance” at the top of the current month. These two numbers should match. If they don't, first check if your "to budget" number is zero. If it's not zero adjust your budget so it is zero.
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

These numbers match because all the money you have in your accounts is in the balance column in the budget. Any changes to accounts (adding transactions) will also change the budget by the same amount, so these numbers stay aligned and you can trust your budget.

<<Budget>>

Now, I want you to go away for a couple days and come back once there are a few transactions in your bank account. We want at least 3 things to practice with but not more than 10. That way it’s manageable for both of us. See you soon.

<<Accounts>>

<<Accounts>>

Hopefully some of the transactions were for expenses you planned on, like maybe you bought groceries. In that row you should see something like $150 budgeted, $76.59 spent and $73.41 balance. That tells you that you have $73.41 left to spend on groceries until you add more to that category.

<<Budget>>

You might also see things like Netflix, $15.49 budgeted, $15.49 spent and $0 balance. That means you budgeted exactly the right amount, paid the bill and have nothing left for that bill at the moment.

<<Budget>>

Scroll through and look for categories like that, where you budgeted money and then spent from what you budgeted. Congratulate yourself on your successful planning.

<<Budget>>

Another thing you might have noticed is categories where you either didn’t budget or didn’t budget enough and then spent. Maybe it’s something like groceries, $150 budgeted, $156.78 spent and -$6.78 balance. Or maybe it’s dining out, $0 budgeted, $11.78 spent and -$11.78 balance.

<<Budget>>

Because we budgeted all your money down to zero that means that if there’s overspending in one place we no longer have the money available for all the other things we budgeted for. That can be discouraging but it’s also empowering.

<<Budget>>

Find a category where you have overspending. I’m assuming you do because everyone does sometimes, even me and I’ve been doing this for many years.

<<Budget>>

Did you find one? Great. You’re taking charge of your money. 
Now, click on the negative number in your overspent category available. 
Select “cover overspending”. 
Now choose the category you want to take money from in the drop down menu.

<<Budget>>

How did that feel? Sometimes it doesn’t feel great because you wanted or needed the money in the category you had to take from. 

To avoid that not great feeling you’ll want to try to check the budget before you spend and decide where you’ll take from at that point and then maybe not spend if there isn’t something you’re willing to use to cover the spending.

<<Budget>>

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at these three dots. This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Click that arrow again, and add a category. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your rent or mortgage.

<<Budget>>

Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
Coach should consider adding a flow for walking a user through how to link accounts with SimpleFin. Consult with Coach Trainers if interested in sample flow.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

First, I'll give you a quick tour of your budget screen. This is where you will be able to see how much money you have for each expense. It's the core of your budgeting experience.

<<Budget>>

This next bit might feel a bit dry but it's important so you know where to find things later.

<<Budget>>

The main feature on this screen is the budget table. Think of it as a digital envelope system where your dollars are waiting to be spent on specific things.

<<Budget>>

The Category column is a list of the things you plan to spend on. Once we're done with our tour our next project is customizing these to your life.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be entering amounts to place dollars in their envelopes. Each month this amount will show how much you put in in that month.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars. These numbers will be generated as you add transactions to your accounts.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

Even the best budgeters sometimes overspend. That's ok, but if you don't adjust your budget to account for this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

<<Budget>>

I'll offer a few quick ideas for optional ways you could edit it and then we'll move on

<<Budget>>

I recommend grouping your budget by frequency of expenses if you're new to budgeting. By that I mean monthly fixed bills as one group. Frequent "live" spending like groceries or dining out as another group. Then longer term bills and longer term variable stuff as the final two groups.

This helps make it easy to see what you need to budget for in what order as money comes in.

<<Budget>>

If money is less tight and your reason for budgeting is better awareness of your spending then organizing by thematic groups works really well.

So you'd have a group for house, car, kids, food and so on.

<<Budget>>

If these ideas have made you rethink things you can drag and drop your categories to rearrange them.

<<Budget>>

One final tip before we move on to accounts.

I like to include the amount and due date in category titles, like "Netflix, $10.59, 16th" so that it's super easy to know how much to put in each category.

This last section is one that is often overlooked in traditional budgeting since we're so used to looking at monthly expense. But there are many expenses that don't occur every month. Instead of letting them sneak up on us we're going to plan for them.

<<Budget>>

These will be our Non-Monthly expenses. Some of them are boring like car registration and others are fun like travel. We will sort these into needs and wants too. One rule I have for myself for these kinds of categories is "would I be willing to go into debt for this if it came around and I wasn't prepared for it?" If the answer is yes (like the car repairs) then it's a need and I make sure that my monthly budget can support saving for my non-monthly needs before I spend on monthly wants.

Now we get to practice the actual, budgeting part of the process. This might feel very different to what you expect budgeting to look like. The main difference is that you’re only going to budget with money that you have right now instead of predicting how much money you will have for the month.

<<Budget>>

<<Budget>>

Ok, now that we understand what the money is that we have to budget, let’s get started.

<<Budget>>

Would you like an analogy or an example?
I'll give you a chance to read both if you want.

<<Budget>>

Imagine you live 50 years ago, when digital banking wasn’t the norm.  You’re doing your budgeting with a pile of cash and a bunch of envelopes. Instead of a bank account balance you have a pile of cash. You put that cash into different envelopes so you know how much is for groceries and how much is for the electric bill. You can’t put cash you don’t have yet in envelopes.

<<Budget>>

Let’s say I have $500 in the bank right now and it’s the middle of the month. I probably don’t need to use any of that money for rent because I already paid that this month. So instead of looking at a generic month budget I look ahead at what’s coming up in real life.

<<Budget>>

Perhaps my phone bill is $120 and due in 3 days. I assign $120 to that. That leaves $380. I know I’m going out for a friend’s birthday this weekend so I put $80 in that category, leaving $300. Typically I spend $150/week on groceries and $50 on gas, so I assign those amounts. That leaves $100 and I don’t have any other immediate needs in the next week before I get another paycheck so I assign the $100 to my travel savings.

<<Budget>>

Then when I get my next paycheck I once again look at bills coming up, regular expenses like groceries, irregular things based on the reality of my next few weeks, and then looking ahead further if I can.
Nope, I got it

<<Budget>>

Do you want to circle back to hear the other?

<<Budget>>

I hope this is making sense so far. Now we're going to apply this idea to your actual money.

<<Budget>>

If you wanted to make a plan for upcoming paychecks you might also jot down notes on the outside of the envelope like “car payment, $200, 25th” so that when you get paid you remember how much to put in. But that doesn’t mean you can pay the car payment before you put the cash in the envelope.

<<Budget>>

By keeping the money in separate envelopes you avoid accidentally spending the electric bill money on groceries. It also lets you easily see at a glance what you can safely spend on dining out or clothes without shorting yourself elsewhere.

Next,  look at your calendar for the time until your next paycheck and think about anything that is coming up that costs money. That might be a doctor’s appointment or a birthday party or a haircut. Fill those in. Make a guess about the amount if it can vary.

<<Budget>>

You will also need to put money into the categories for things that happen often, most commonly these are groceries and gas but your budget might include other frequent expenses. Put money in all of these. But you don’t need to put in a whole month worth, just enough until you get paid again.
I'm done

<<Budget>>

You’ve accounted for all your immediate needs and still have money left to budget. That’s awesome. I’ll give you a few things to think about so that we can make sure all that money is safely in budget categories. Deciding what the money is for before spending it is a really important step in having a successful budget. I've saved the "I'm done" option for the end of these suggestions so you can click through them all and make an informed choice with the rest of your money.

<<Budget>>

Ok, did you budget exactly to zero? If not, go ahead and make a quick adjustment. Specifically, if to budgeted has a few dollars left go ahead and put exactly that amount in a savings goal or fun money or something. If you’ve gone a bit into the negative then adjust a category so it has a bit less and to budgeted is back up to zero.

<<Budget>>

Nicely done, now, if you had to stop before you covered your needs that’s important information for you. It means you might have to delay some needs or get creative until you’re paid again. If you met all your needs then you can feel comfortable spending those funds, but be sure to check the budget if you spend on things you hadn’t planned on.

<<Budget>>

Is some of the remaining money because you’d already been saving up for specific things like an upcoming car repair, vacation or other large expense? Assign funds to those categories based on what you’d already planned to do with that money.

<<Budget>>

Are there times of the month when your bills cluster and things get tight with that paycheck? You could consider assigning some money to those bills ahead of time so it’s not so tight then.

<<Budget>>

Are there longer term expenses that you could start saving for, like annual memberships, seasonal clothing shopping, planting a garden or holidays?
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Do you have debt you can work on paying down? Or big savings goals like retirement that you want to work on bulking up?

Now go ahead and assign the remainder of your money.

<<Budget>>

Now that all your money is budgeted I want to show you something. Look at the number next to “for budget” in the far left column.

<<Budget>>

Now look at the number under “balance” at the top of the current month. These two numbers should match. If they don't, first check if your "to budget" number is zero.
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

That’s because all the money you have in your accounts is in the balance column in the budget. Any changes to accounts (adding transactions) will also change the budget by the same amount, so these numbers stay aligned and you can trust your budget.

<<Budget>>

Now, I want you to go away for a couple days and come back once there are a few transactions in your bank account. We want at least 3 things to practice with but not more than 10. That way it’s manageable for both of us. See you soon.

<<Account>>

Now you’ll hit “add new” and add each transaction that has occurred since that starting balance.

<<Account>>

Click “add new”. Choose the date the spending happened. Type in a payee, that means where you spent the money, like Costco or Amazon. Add a note if you want about what you bought. Choose a category from the list. If your list is long you can start typing a name in the box and it’ll search for it. Enter the exact amount in the payment box. Click save.

<<Account>>

Add more transactions in that same way until you’ve added all the recent ones. If it’s income then enter the amount under deposit not payment.

<<Account>>

Great work. You're picking this up quickly.

<<Account>>

Does the balance at the top of the account match your bank in real life?

<<Account>>

Great, let's head over to the budget screen

<<Account>>

No problem, here are some things to check

<<Budget>>

Let’s check out what happened in the budget when you added those transactions.

<<Budget>>

Hopefully some of the transactions were for expenses you planned on, like maybe you bought groceries. In that row you should see something like $150 budgeted, $76.59 spent and $73.41 balance. That tells you that you have $73.41 left to spend on groceries until you add more to that category.

<<Budget>>

You might also see things like Netflix, $15.49 budgeted, $15.49 spent and $0 balance. That means you budgeted exactly the right amount, paid the bill and have nothing left for that bill at the moment.

<<Budget>>

Scroll through and look for categories like that, where you budgeted money and then spent from what you budgeted.

<<Budget>>

Another thing you might have noticed is categories where you either didn’t budget or didn’t budget enough and then spent. Maybe it’s something like groceries, $150 budgeted, $156.78 spent and -$6.78 balance. Or maybe it’s dining out, $0 budgeted, $11.78 spent and -$11.78 balance.

<<Budget>>

Because we budgeted all your money down to zero that means that if there’s overspending in one place we no longer have the money available for all the other things we budgeted for. That can be depressing but it’s also empowering.

<<Budget>>

Find a category where you have overspending. I’m assuming you do because everyone does sometimes, even me and I’ve been doing this for many years.

<<Budget>>

Now you get to make a choice, what will you spend less on now to account for spending more than planned on this other thing? Scroll through your budget and find a category that has money in the balance column that you don’t need all of.

<<Budget>>

Did you find one? Great. You’re taking charge of your money. Now, click on the negative number in your overspent category available. Select “cover overspending”. Now choose the category you want to take money from in the drop down menu.

<<Budget>>

How did that feel? Sometimes it doesn’t feel great because you wanted or needed the money in the category you had to take from. To avoid that not great feeling you’ll want to try to check the budget before you spend and decide where you’ll take from at that point and then maybe not spend if there isn’t something you’re willing to use to cover the spending.

<<Budget>>

At this point you should go ahead and cover any other overspending that happened. You could also do some more budgeting if you received income since we saw each other last.

<<Budget>>

You have all the tools you need to start building a life that has less financial stress. I’m so proud of you for sticking with it this far. Just a couple more things to wrap up our initial conversation but I promise, I’ll be checking in on you as you go.
